1.verse: The Census and the Preparation to Depart from Sinai -Chapter 1 -The Census. -The Lord spoke to Moses in the Sinai Desert in the tent of meeting on the first day of the second month of the second year after they left the land of Egypt, saying,

2.verse: “Take a census of the community of the people of Israel, arranging them by their families, by their clans, listing every single man by name.

3.verse: You and Aaron will count them, company by company, each one who is twenty years and older and is able to go to war in Israel.

4.verse: A man from every tribe, the head of his clan, will accompany you.

5.verse: Assistants to Moses Named. -“These are the names of the men who will accompany you: from the tribe of Reuben, Elizur, the son of Shedeur;

6.verse: from the tribe of Simeon, Shelumiel, the son of Zurishaddai;

7.verse: from the tribe of Judah, Nahshon, the son of Amminadab;

8.verse: from the tribe of Issachar, Nathanel, the son of Zuar;

9.verse: from the tribe of Zebulun, Eliab, the son of Helon;

10.verse: from the son of Joseph, from the tribe of Ephraim, Elishama, the son of Ammihud, and from the tribe of Manasseh, Gamaliel, the son of Pedahzur;

11.verse: from the tribe of Benjamin, Abidan, the son of Gideoni;

12.verse: from Dan, Ahiezer, the son of Ammishaddai;

13.verse: from Asher, Pagiel, the son of Ochran;

14.verse: from Gad, Eliasaph, the son of Reuel;

15.verse: from Naphtali, Ahira, the son of Enan.”

16.verse: These were the ones summoned from the assembly, the leaders of their tribes. They were the heads of the clans of Israel.

17.verse: Moses and Aaron took the men who had been named

18.verse: and on the first day of the second month they gathered together the entire community who registered themselves by families, by the name of their fathers’ households. The men twenty years and older were listed according to their names, one by one,

19.verse: as the Lord had commanded Moses. And so he counted them in the Sinai Desert.

20.verse: The Count of the Twelve Tribes. -Thus the members of the tribe of Reuben, the oldest son of Israel, who were twenty years or older and who were fit to bear arms were listed by name according to their clans and families, one by one.

21.verse: The number of men in the tribe of Reuben was forty-six thousand, five hundred.

22.verse: The members of the tribe of Simeon who were twenty years or older and who were fit to bear arms were listed by name according to their clans and families, one by one.

23.verse: The number of men in the tribe of Simeon was fifty-nine thousand, three hundred.

24.verse: The members of the tribe of Gad who were twenty years or older and who were fit to bear arms were listed by name according to their clans and families.

25.verse: The number of men in the tribe of Gad was forty-five thousand, six hundred fifty.

26.verse: The members of the tribe of Judah who were twenty years or older and who were fit to bear arms were listed by name according to their clans and families.

27.verse: The number of men in the tribe of Judah was seventy-four thousand, six hundred.

28.verse: The members of the tribe of Issachar who were twenty years or older and who were fit to bear arms were listed by name according to their clans and families.

29.verse: The number of men in the tribe of Issachar was fifty-four thousand, four hundred.

30.verse: The members of the tribe of Zebulun who were twenty years or older and who were fit to bear arms were listed by name according to their clans and families.

31.verse: The number of men in the tribe of Zebulun was fifty-seven thousand, four hundred.

32.verse: The sons of Joseph include the members of the tribe of Ephraim who were twenty years or older and who were fit to bear arms. They were listed by name according to their clans and families.

33.verse: The number of men in the tribe of Ephraim was forty thousand, five hundred.

34.verse: There are also the members of the tribe of Manasseh who were twenty years or older and who were fit to bear arms. They were listed by name according to their clans and families.

35.verse: The number of men in the tribe of Manasseh was thirty-two thousand, two hundred.

36.verse: The members of the tribe of Benjamin who were twenty years or older and who were fit to bear arms were listed by name according to their clans and families.

37.verse: The number of men in the tribe of Benjamin was thirty-five thousand, four hundred.

38.verse: The members of the tribe of Dan who were twenty years or older and who were fit to bear arms were listed by name according to their clans and families.

39.verse: The number of men in the tribe of Dan was sixty-two thousand, seven hundred.

40.verse: The members of the tribe of Asher who were twenty years or older and who were fit to bear arms were listed by name according to their clans and families, one by one.

41.verse: The number of men in the tribe of Asher was forty-one thousand, five hundred.

42.verse: The members of the tribe of Naphtali who were twenty years or older and who were fit to bear arms were listed by name according to their clans and families, one by one.

43.verse: The number of men in the tribe of Naphtali was fifty-three thousand, four hundred.

44.verse: This was the number of men counted by Moses and Aaron and the twelve leaders, each representing his ancestral clan.

45.verse: The total number of the people of Israel who were listed according to their clan who were twenty years or older and fit to bear arms in Israel

46.verse: was six hundred and three thousand, five hundred and fifty.

47.verse: Responsibility of the Levites. -The families of the tribe of Levi, however, were not counted with the rest of them

48.verse: for the Lord had said to Moses,

49.verse: “You are not to take a census of the tribe of Levi, nor are you to include them in the census of the people of Israel.

50.verse: You will assign the Levites responsibility over the tent of the tabernacle and over all of its vessels and over all of the things that belong to it. They will carry the tabernacle and all of its vessels. They will care for it and they will camp around the tabernacle.

51.verse: When the tabernacle is to be moved, the Levites will take it down. When it is to be erected, the Levites will set it up. Anyone else who approaches it must be put to death.

52.verse: “Each of the Israelites will pitch his tent within his own camp, alongside his own standard, each in his own company,

53.verse: but the Levites will camp around the tabernacle of the Testimony so that no wrath come upon the community of the people of Israel. The Levites will keep guard over the tabernacle of the Testimony.”

54.verse: This is what the people of Israel did. They did everything that the Lord had commanded Moses.

1.verse: Chapter 2 -Placement of the Tribal Camps. -The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,

2.verse: “Every Israelite will camp by their own standard, alongside the emblems of their father’s household. They will camp some distance from the tent of meeting.

3.verse: “On the east side, toward the rising of the sun, will be the standard of the camp of Judah arranged by their companies. The leader of the tribe of Judah is Nahshon, the son of Amminadab.

4.verse: His forces numbered seventy-four thousand, six hundred.

5.verse: The tribe of Issachar will camp next to him. The leader of the tribe of Issachar is Nethanel, the son of Zuar.

6.verse: His forces numbered fifty-four thousand, four hundred.

7.verse: Then there is the tribe of Zebulun. The leader of the tribe of Zebulun is Eliab, the son of Helon.

8.verse: His forces numbered fifty-seven thousand, four hundred.

9.verse: The whole camp of Judah, by their companies, numbered one hundred eighty-six thousand, four hundred. They are to set out first on the march.

10.verse: “On the south side of the camp is the standard of the camp of Reuben, arranged by their companies. The leader of the tribe of Reuben is Elizur, the son of Shedeur.

11.verse: His forces numbered forty-six thousand, five hundred.

12.verse: The tribe of Simeon will camp next to him. The leader of the tribe of Simeon is Shelumiel, the son of Zurushaddai.

13.verse: His forces numbered fifty-nine thousand, three hundred.

14.verse: Then there is the tribe of Gad. The leader of the tribe of Gad is Eliasaph, the son of Reuel.

15.verse: His forces numbered forty-five thousand, six hundred fifty.

16.verse: The whole camp of Reuben, by their companies, numbered one hundred fifty-one thousand, four hundred fifty. They are to be the second to set out on the march.

17.verse: “Then the tent of meeting will set out, with the camp of the Levites in the middle of the other camps whenever they set up camp. This is how they are to set out, each man located under his own standards.

18.verse: “On the west side of the camp is the standard of the camp of Ephraim, arranged by their companies. The leader of the tribe of Ephraim is Elishama, the son of Ammihud.

19.verse: His forces numbered forty thousand, five hundred.

20.verse: The tribe of Manasseh will camp next to him. The leader of the tribe of Manasseh is Gamaliel, the son of Pedahzur.

21.verse: His forces numbered thirty-two thousand, two hundred.

22.verse: Then comes the tribe of Benjamin. The leader of the tribe of Benjamin is Abidan, the son of Gideoni.

23.verse: His forces numbered thirty-five thousand, five hundred.

24.verse: The whole camp of Ephraim, by their companies, numbered one hundred eight thousand, one hundred. They are to be the third to set out on the march.

25.verse: “On the north side of the camp is the standard of the camp of Dan, arranged by their companies. The leader of the tribe of Dan is Ahiezer, the son of Ammishaddai.

26.verse: His forces numbered sixty-two thousand, seven hundred.

27.verse: The tribe of Asher will camp next to him. The leader of the tribe of Asher is Pagiel, the son of Ochran.

28.verse: His forces numbered forty-one thousand, five hundred.

29.verse: Then comes the tribe of Naphtali. The leader of the tribe of Naphtali is Ahira, the son of Enan.

30.verse: His forces numbered fifty-three thousand, four hundred.

31.verse: The whole camp of Dan, by their companies, numbered one hundred fifty-seven thousand, six hundred. They are to march last with their standards.”

32.verse: These were the people of Israel who were counted. There were six hundred three thousand, five hundred and fifty counted in their camps, in their companies,

33.verse: but the Levites were not counted along with the people of Israel, as the Lord had commanded Moses.

34.verse: The people of Israel did everything as the Lord had commanded Moses by encamping under their standards and by the way they set out, each going with his clan and his family.

1.verse: Chapter 3 -Aaron’s Offspring. -These are the descendants of Aaron and Moses on the day that the Lord spoke to Moses on Mount Sinai.

2.verse: These are the names of the sons of Aaron: the oldest was Nadab, and then there were Abihu and Eleazar and Ithamar.

3.verse: These are the names of the sons of Aaron, the priests who were anointed and consecrated to minister in the priesthood.

4.verse: Nadab and Abihu died before the Lord when they offered unclean fire to the Lord in the Sinai Desert. They had no children. Eleazar and Ithamar ministered as priests in the presence of their father Aaron.

5.verse: The Tribe of Levi. -The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

6.verse: “Gather the tribe of Levi and have them stand before Aaron the priest so that they can minister to him.

7.verse: They will serve him and serve the whole assembly standing before the tent of meeting, ministering to the needs of the tabernacle.

8.verse: They will take care of all of the furnishings of the tent of meeting and attend to the needs of the people of Israel as they minister in the tabernacle.

9.verse: You will give the Levites to Aaron and his sons; they are dedicated to him from among the people of Israel.

10.verse: You will appoint Aaron and his sons, and they will serve as priests. Anyone else who draws near is to be put to death.”

11.verse: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

12.verse: “Behold, I have taken the Levites from among the people of Israel as a substitute for the firstborn of the people of Israel, those who opened the womb. The Levites will be my own,

13.verse: for every firstborn has belonged to me from the day that I slew all the firstborn in the land of Egypt. I have set apart all the firstborn as my own in Israel, both human and animal. They will be mine. I am the Lord.”

14.verse: Counting the Levites. -The Lord spoke to Moses in the Sinai Desert, saying,

15.verse: “Count the sons of Levi by clan, by family. Count every male one month old and older.”

16.verse: So Moses counted them, as the word of the Lord had commanded him.

17.verse: These are the names of the sons of Levi: Gershon, Kohath and Merari.

18.verse: These are the names of the sons of Gershon by their families: Libni and Shimei.

19.verse: The sons of Kohath by their families were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

20.verse: The sons of Merari by the families were Mahli and Mushi. These are the families of the Levites according to their clan.

21.verse: From Gershon came the family of the Libnites and the family of the Shimeites. These are the families of the Gershonites.

22.verse: They counted them, all males one month old and older, and they numbered seven thousand, five hundred.

23.verse: The clan of the Gershonites were to camp behind the tabernacle to the west.

24.verse: Eliasaph, the son of Lael, was the leader of the clan of the Gershonites.

25.verse: In the tent of meeting the sons of Gershon had responsibility for the care of the tabernacle, the tent with its covering, the screen for the entrance to the tent of meeting,

26.verse: the curtains for the courtyard, the screen for the entrance to the courtyard that surrounds the tabernacle and the altar, its cords, and everything that had to be done with these.

27.verse: From Kohath came the family of the Amramites, the family of the Izharites, the family of the Hebronites, and the family of the Uzzielites. These are the families of the Kohathites.

28.verse: They counted them, all males one month old and older, and they numbered eight thousand, three hundred, ministering to the needs of the sanctuary.

29.verse: The clan of the Kohathites were to camp on the south side of the tabernacle.

30.verse: Elizaphan, the son of Uzziel, was the leader of the clan of the Kohathites.

31.verse: Their responsibility was for the Ark, the table, the lampstand, the altars, the vessels of the sanctuary, the screen, and everything that had to be done with these.

32.verse: Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest, was to be the supervisor of the leaders of the Levites. He was to oversee those who had the responsibility to care for the needs of the sanctuary.

33.verse: From Merari came the family of the Mahlites, and the family of the Mushites. These are the families of Merari.

34.verse: They counted them, all males one month old and older, and they numbered six thousand, two hundred.

35.verse: Zuriel, the son of Abihail, was the leader of the clan of Merari. They were to camp on the north side of the tabernacle.

36.verse: Their responsibility was for the boards of the tabernacle, and its bars, its pillars, its sockets and all of their parts,

37.verse: the pillars around the courtyard, and their pins, and their cords.

38.verse: Finally, Moses, Aaron and his sons camped in front of the tabernacle on its east side, in front of the tent of meeting and eastward. They kept watch over the sanctuary, keeping the people of Israel and any other person from coming near, under penalty of death.

39.verse: The total number of the Levites who were counted by Moses and Aaron at the command of the Lord, everyone in their families who was one month old and older, was twenty-two thousand.

40.verse: Redemption of the Firstborn. -The Lord said to Moses, “Count all the firstborn males of the people of Israel, those one month old and older, and make a list of their names.

41.verse: The Levites will be a substitute for me in place of the firstborn of the people of Israel. I am the Lord. The cattle of the Levites will be a substitute for the firstborn of the cattle of the people of Israel.”

42.verse: Moses counted all of the firstborn of the people of Israel as the Lord had commanded him

43.verse: and he listed all the firstborn males by name, those one month old and older. They numbered twenty-two thousand, two hundred seventy-three.

44.verse: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

45.verse: “Take the Levites as a substitute for all the firstborn of the people of Israel, and the cattle of the Levites as a substitute for their cattle. The Levites are mine. I am the Lord.”

46.verse: Those who were to be redeemed among the firstborn of the people of Israel, not counting the Levites, numbered two hundred seventy-three.

47.verse: “You will take five shekels for each person according to the shekel of the sanctuary, that is, twenty gerahs for each shekel

48.verse: and give the money to Aaron and his sons to redeem those who are in excess among them.”

49.verse: Moses took the redemption money for those who were in excess, above the number of those redeemed by the Levites.

50.verse: He received the money for the firstborn of the people of Israel, one thousand three hundred and sixty-five shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary.

51.verse: Moses gave the redemption money to Aaron and his sons as the Lord had commanded Moses by the word of the Lord.

1.verse: Chapter 4 -Delineation of Duties. -The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,

2.verse: “Count the number of the Kohathites from among the sons of Levi by their clans and their families.

3.verse: Count all the men from thirty to fifty years old who go in to minister in the tent of meeting.

4.verse: “This is the ministry of the Kohathites in the tent of meeting: tending to the most holy things.

5.verse: When the camp is being moved, Aaron and his sons will take down the veil and cover the Ark of Testimony with it.

6.verse: They are then to put on the sheep skins, cover it with a blue cloth, and put the poles in place.

7.verse: They will spread a blue cloth over the table for the shewbread. On it they will place the dishes and spoons and bowls and jars for the drink offerings. The bread of offering will remain on it.

8.verse: Over these they will spread a scarlet cloth and cover it with sheep skins. You will then put the poles in it.

9.verse: They are to take a blue cloth and cover the lampstand used for the light, its lamps, its tongs, its snuffers, and all of its oil dishes, all the things used in its ministry.

10.verse: They will put it and all of its vessels within a hide of sheep skin and they will put it upon a litter.

11.verse: They will spread a blue cloth upon the golden altar and cover it with a covering of sheep skins and put its poles in it.

12.verse: Then they are to take all the implements with which they minister in the sanctuary, and they are to cover them with a blue cloth and with a covering of sheep skin and put them on a litter.

13.verse: They are to empty all the ashes out from the altar and spread a purple cloth on it.

14.verse: They are to put all the utensils with which they minister upon it, the censers, the forks, the shovels, and the basins. They are to take all of the utensils with which they minister and spread a sheep skin upon them. They will also put in its poles.

15.verse: “When Aaron and his sons have finished covering the sanctuary and all of the vessels of the sanctuary, when the camp is ready to set out, the Kohathites will come forward to carry it, but they will not touch anything that is holy, lest they die. These things in the tent of meeting are the responsibility of the Kohathites.

16.verse: “Eleazar, the son of Aaron, has the responsibility for the oil for the light, the sweet incense, the daily meat offering, and the oil for anointing. He shall also oversee care for the tabernacle and everything in it, the sanctuary and its vessels.”

17.verse: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,

18.verse: “Do not let the clan of the Kohathites be cut off from among the Levites.

19.verse: Do these things for them so that they may live. Otherwise they will die when they come near to the most holy things. Aaron and his sons will go and appoint each one of them to their ministry and their responsibilities,

20.verse: only they are not to go in and watch while the holy things are being covered, lest they die.”

21.verse: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

22.verse: “Count the number of the sons of Gershon by their clans and their families.

23.verse: Count all the men from thirty to fifty years old who go in to minister in the tent of meeting.

24.verse: This is the ministry of the clan of the Gershonites, their service and responsibility.

25.verse: They will carry the curtains of the tabernacle and the tent of meeting with its covering, the covering of sheep skin that is over it, the screen for the entrance to the tent of meeting,

26.verse: the curtains for the courtyard, the screen for the entrance to the courtyard that surrounds the tabernacle and the altar, their cords, and all of their accessories. They will do all that needs to be done with these things.

27.verse: All the service of the Gershonites, what they are to carry and what they are to do, will be under the direction of Aaron and his sons. You are to assign them responsibility for what they are to carry.

28.verse: These things in the tent of meeting are the responsibility of the families of the Gershonites. Their service will be under the direction of Ithamar, the son of Aaron the priest.

29.verse: “Count the number of the Merarites by their clans and their families.

30.verse: Count all the men from thirty to fifty years old who go in to minister in the tent of meeting.

31.verse: This is their responsibility and service for the tent of meeting: the boards of the tabernacle with their bars, their pillars, their sockets,

32.verse: the pillars surrounding the courtyard, their sockets, their pins, their cords, and all their accessories. You will assign the things that they are charged to carry by name.

33.verse: This is the service of the clan of the Merarites. All of their service in the tent of meeting will be under the direction of Ithamar, the son of Aaron, the priest.”

34.verse: Counting the Adult Levites. -Moses and Aaron and the leaders of the assembly counted the Kohathites by family and by clan,

35.verse: those who were from thirty to fifty years old and who went in to minister in the service of the tent of meeting.

36.verse: By families there were two thousand, seven hundred and fifty.

37.verse: This was the number of those in the families of the Kohathites who ministered in the tent of meeting, whom Moses and Aaron counted, fulfilling the commandment of the Lord given to Moses.

38.verse: The sons of Gershon were counted by families and clan

39.verse: counting those who were from thirty years old to fifty years old and who went in to minister in the service of the tent of meeting.

40.verse: Counted by family and clan, there were two thousand, six hundred and thirty of them.

41.verse: This was the number of the families of the sons of Gershon, all of whom served in the tent of meeting, whom Moses and Aaron counted, fulfilling the commandment of the Lord.

42.verse: The Merarites were counted by families and clan,

43.verse: those who were from thirty years old to fifty years old and who went in to minister in the service of the tent of meeting.

44.verse: Counted by families, there were three thousand, two hundred of them.

45.verse: This was the number of the families of the Merarites whom Moses and Aaron counted, fulfilling the commandment of the Lord given to Moses.

46.verse: Moses and Aaron and the leaders of Israel counted all of the Levites according to families and clans

47.verse: who were from thirty years old to fifty years old, everyone who could enter to do the work of ministry and who served carrying the tent of meeting.

48.verse: There were eight thousand, five hundred and eighty of them.

49.verse: They were counted as the Lord had commanded Moses, counting all of those dedicated for service and carrying, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.

1.verse: Chapter 5 -Purifying the Camp. -The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

2.verse: “Command the people of Israel to expel from the camp every leper and everyone who has a discharge and everyone who is unclean because they touched the dead.

3.verse: You will expel both men and women from the camp. You will put them out so that they do not make the camp unclean, for I dwell in their midst.”

4.verse: The people of Israel did this, putting them outside of the camp. The Israelites did what the Lord had instructed Moses.

5.verse: Making Recompense. -The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

6.verse: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘When a man or a woman sins in any way, that person has been unfaithful to the Lord and will be considered to be guilty.

7.verse: He will confess the sin that he has committed. He will recompense his trespass, taking the full amount and one-fifth more and give it to the person against whom he has committed this offense.

8.verse: But if the person offended has no kinsmen who could receive the recompense for the trespass, then let the trespass be paid to the Lord, to the priest, besides the ram that is being used to obtain his atonement.

9.verse: Every offering of holy things that the people of Israel bring to the priest will belong to him.

10.verse: Everyone’s gift of holy things will belong to him; whatever is given to the priest belongs to him.’ ”

11.verse: The Test of Unfaithfulness. -The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

12.verse: “Speak to the people of Israel and say to them, ‘If any man’s wife goes astray and is unfaithful to him,

13.verse: and a man has sex with her, and this is hidden from her husband, and she is defiled but keeps it a secret since there are no witnesses and she was not caught in the act,

14.verse: and if a spirit of jealousy comes upon him, and he is jealous of his wife because she has defiled herself, or if a spirit of jealousy comes upon him and he is jealous of her even though she has not defiled herself,

15.verse: then he will take his wife to the priest. He will also bring an offering for her, a tenth of an ephah of barley meal in which he has not poured oil nor put frankincense. This is a jealousy offering.

16.verse: “ ‘The priest will bring her and have her stand before the Lord.

17.verse: The priest will put some holy water in a clay vessel and he will put some of the dust from the floor of the sanctuary into the water.

18.verse: The priest will have the woman stand before the Lord. He will uncover her hair and he will place the jealousy memorial offering in her hands. The priest will hold the bitter water that brings on a curse in his hands.

19.verse: The priest will have the woman swear an oath saying, “If no other man has slept with you and if you have not gone astray, becoming defiled while married to your husband, then you will be free from the curse that this bitter water causes.

20.verse: But if you have gone astray while married to your husband, becoming defiled, and you have had sex with someone other than your husband,”

21.verse: (at this point the priest will have the woman swear an oath to curse herself, and the priest will say to the woman) “then may the Lord make you a curse and a blight among your people. May the Lord make your loins rot and your womb swell;

22.verse: this water that brings on a curse will descend to your womb causing it to swell and your loins to rot.” The woman will then say, “Amen, amen.”

23.verse: The priest will write these curses in a book and blot them out with the bitter water.

24.verse: He will have the woman drink the bitter water that brings on the curse. The water that brings on the curse will enter her and will become bitter.

25.verse: The priest will then take the jealousy offering out of the woman’s hand and wave the offering before the Lord and offer it upon the altar.

26.verse: The priest will take a handful of the offering as the memorial offering and will burn it upon the altar. After that he will have the woman drink the water.

27.verse: When he has made her drink the water, if she has defiled herself and been unfaithful to her husband, the curse in the water will enter her and be bitter and will cause her womb to swell and her loins to rot.

28.verse: But if the woman has not defiled herself and she is clean, then she will be unharmed and will conceive children.

29.verse: “ ‘This is the law of jealousy, when a wife goes astray while married to her husband and becomes defiled

30.verse: or when the spirit of jealousy comes upon him and he is jealous of his wife. He will bring his wife before the Lord and the priest will fulfill all the prescriptions of this law upon her.

31.verse: The man will be free from guilt, but the woman will bear her guilt.’ ”

1.verse: Chapter 6 -Nazirite Laws. -The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

2.verse: “Speak to the people of Israel and say to them, ‘If a man or a woman dedicates himself or herself with a vow, a Nazirite vow to dedicate himself or herself unto the Lord,

3.verse: that person will abstain from wine and strong drink. He will not drink any vinegar made from wine or from strong drink, nor will he drink any grape juice, nor will he eat grapes or raisins.

4.verse: He is not to eat anything that comes from the vine, not even the seeds or the skins as long as he is a Nazirite.

5.verse: No razor will touch his head all throughout the time of his vow. He is to be holy until the days of his vow have been completed. He will let the hair on his head grow long.

6.verse: He is not to approach any dead body during the entire period of his vow to the Lord.

7.verse: He is not to make himself unclean even for his father or mother if they were to die, nor his brother or sister, for the consecration of God is upon his head.

8.verse: He is to be holy to the Lord all the days of his vow.

9.verse: “ ‘But if someone were to die suddenly in his presence and defile his consecrated head, he is to shave his head on the day of his cleansing and he will shave it again on the seventh day.

10.verse: Then on the eighth day he will bring two turtledoves or two young pigeons to the priest at the entrance to the tent of meeting.

11.verse: The priest will offer one of them as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering making atonement for the uncleanness caused by the dead person. On that same day he is to consecrate his head

12.verse: and he will dedicate his days of consecration unto the Lord. He will bring a year-old male lamb as a guilt offering. The days that preceded this incident will not count, however, for his dedicated head had been defiled.

13.verse: “ ‘This is the law concerning Nazirites when the time of their dedication is completed. He is to be brought to the entrance to the tent of meeting.

14.verse: He will bring a year-old male lamb without defect unto the Lord as a burnt offering, and a one-year-old ewe lamb without defect for a sin offering, and a one-year-old ram without defect as a peace offering

15.verse: and a basket of unleavened bread made from fine flour mixed with oil, and unleavened wafers of bread with oil spread on them, and a cereal offering, and a drink offering.

16.verse: The priest will bring them before the Lord and he will offer his sin offering and his burnt offering.

17.verse: He will offer the ram as the sacrifice of a peace offering unto the Lord together with the basket of unleavened bread. The priest will also offer the cereal offering and the drink offering.

18.verse: The Nazirite will shave his head at the entrance to the tent of meeting. He will take the hair that grew during the period when he was vowed and put it on the fire under the sacrifice of the peace offering.

19.verse: The priest will take a shoulder of the ram that has been boiled, and an unleavened cake out of the basket, and an unleavened wafer, and he will put them into the hands of the Nazirite who has shaved off the hair of his vow.

20.verse: The priest will wave them as a wave offering before the Lord. It is holy and will belong to the priest, along with the breast of the wave offering and the thigh that was presented. After this the Nazirite can drink wine.

21.verse: This is the law of the Nazirite who has vowed his offering unto the Lord for his consecration (apart from what else he can afford). He must fulfill what he has vowed to do by the Nazirite law.’ ”

22.verse: The Priests’ Blessing. -The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

23.verse: “Speak to Aaron and his sons, saying, ‘This is how you will bless the people of Israel, saying to them,

24.verse: “ ‘ “The Lord bless you and keep you.

25.verse: The Lord shine his face upon you and be gracious to you.

26.verse: The Lord look upon you kindly and give you peace.” ’

27.verse: They will invoke my name upon the people of Israel, and I will bless them.”

1.verse: Chapter 7 -Tribal Offerings. -The day that Moses completed setting up the tabernacle, he anointed it and consecrated it and all of its furnishings, including the altar and all of its utensils. He anointed and consecrated them.

2.verse: The leaders of Israel, the heads of the clans, and the leaders of the tribes that had been counted in the census, made their offerings.

3.verse: They brought their offerings before the Lord: six covered wagons and twelve oxen. There was a wagon for each two leaders, and an oxen for each of them. They brought them before the tabernacle.

4.verse: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

5.verse: “Accept these things from them so that they might be used in the service of the tent of meeting. Give them to the Levites, each according to his responsibility.”

6.verse: Moses took the wagons and the oxen and gave them to the Levites.

7.verse: He gave two wagons and four oxen to the Gershonites for their responsibilities.

8.verse: He also gave four wagons and eight oxen to the Merarites for their responsibilities. They were under the direction of Ithamar, the son of Aaron the priest.

9.verse: None of them were given to the Kohathites, for it was their job to carry their portion of the tabernacle upon their shoulders.

10.verse: The leaders also presented offerings to commemorate the dedication of the altar on the day that it was anointed. The leaders placed their offerings before the altar.

11.verse: The Lord said to Moses, “Let each of the leaders present his offering for the dedication of the altar on successive days.”

12.verse: Nahshon, the son of Amminadab of the tribe of Judah, presented his offering on the first day.

13.verse: His offering was one silver dish that weighed one hundred and thirty shekels and one bowl weighing seventy shekels, both calculated according to the shekel of the sanctuary. Both vessels were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering.

14.verse: He also brought one gold pan weighing ten shekels, filled with incense,

15.verse: one young bull, one young ram, one year-old male lamb for a burnt offering,

16.verse: one male goat for a sin offering,

17.verse: and two oxen, five rams, and five year-old male lambs for a peace offering. This was the offering of Nahshon, the son of Amminadab.

18.verse: Nethanel, the son of Zuar, the leader of the people of Issachar, brought his offering on the second day.

19.verse: His offering was one silver dish that weighed one hundred and thirty shekels and one bowl weighing seventy shekels, both calculated according to the shekel of the sanctuary. Both vessels were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering.

20.verse: He also brought one gold pan weighing ten shekels, filled with incense,

21.verse: one young bull, one young ram, one year-old male lamb for a burnt offering,

22.verse: one male goat for a sin offering,

23.verse: and two oxen, five rams, and five year-old male lambs for a peace offering. This was the offering of Nethanel, the son of Zuar.

24.verse: Eliab, the son of Helon, the leader of the people of Zebulun, presented on the third day

25.verse: his offering of one silver dish that weighed one hundred and thirty shekels and one bowl weighing seventy shekels, both calculated according to the shekel of the sanctuary. Both vessels were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering.

26.verse: He also brought one gold pan weighing ten shekels, filled with incense,

27.verse: one young bull, one young ram, one year-old male lamb for a burnt offering,

28.verse: one male goat for a sin offering,

29.verse: and two oxen, five rams, and five year-old male lambs for a peace offering. This was the offering of Eliab, the son of Helon.

30.verse: Elizur, the son of Shedeur, the leader of the people of Reuben, presented on the fourth day

31.verse: his offering of one silver dish that weighed one hundred and thirty shekels and one bowl weighing seventy shekels, both calculated according to the shekel of the sanctuary. Both vessels were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering.

32.verse: He also brought one gold pan weighing ten shekels, filled with incense,

33.verse: one young bull, one young ram, one year-old male lamb for a burnt offering,

34.verse: one male goat for a sin offering,

35.verse: and two oxen, five rams, and five year-old male lambs for a peace offering. This was the offering of Elizur, the son of Shedeur.

36.verse: Shelumiel, the son of Zurishaddai, the leader of the people of Simeon, presented on the fifth day

40.verse: one male goat for a sin offering,

41.verse: and two oxen, five rams, and five year-old male lambs for a peace offering. This was the offering of Shelumiel, the son of Zurishaddai.

42.verse: Eliasaph, the son of Reuel, the leader of the people of Gad, presented on the sixth day

46.verse: one male goat for a sin offering,

47.verse: and two oxen, five rams, and five year-old male lambs for a peace offering. This was the offering of Eliasaph, the son of Reuel.

48.verse: Elishama, the son of Ammihud, the leader of the people of Ephraim, presented on the seventh day

49.verse: his offering of one silver dish that weighed one hundred and thirty shekels and one bowl weighing seventy shekels, both calculated according to the shekel of the sanctuary. Both vessels were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering.

54.verse: Gamaliel, the son of Pedahzur, the leader of the people of Manasseh, presented on the eighth day

55.verse: his offering of one silver dish that weighed one hundred and thirty shekels and one bowl weighing seventy shekels, both calculated according to the shekel of the sanctuary. Both vessels were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering.

60.verse: Abidan, the son of Gideoni, the leader of the people of Benjamin, presented on the ninth day

61.verse: his offering of one silver dish that weighed one hundred and thirty shekels and one bowl weighing seventy shekels, both calculated according to the shekel of the sanctuary. Both vessels were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering.

78.verse: Ahira, the son of Enan, the leader of the people of Naphtali, presented on the twelfth day

79.verse: his offering of one silver dish that weighed one hundred and thirty shekels and one bowl weighing seventy shekels, both calculated according to the shekel of the sanctuary. Both vessels were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering.

80.verse: He also brought one gold pan weighing ten shekels, filled with incense,

82.verse: one male goat for a sin offering,

83.verse: and two oxen, five rams, and five year-old male lambs for a peace offering. This was the offering of Ahira, the son of Enan.

84.verse: This was the dedication offering from the leaders of Israel for the altar on the day that it was anointed: twelve silver dishes, twelve silver bowls and twelve gold pans.

85.verse: Each silver dish weighed one hundred and thirty shekels and each silver bowl seventy shekels. All the silver vessels together weighed two thousand and four hundred shekels, calculated according to the shekel of the sanctuary.

86.verse: The twelve gold pans full of incense weighed ten shekels each, calculated according to the shekel of the sanctuary. All together the gold pans weighed one hundred and twenty shekels.

87.verse: There were twelve bull oxen for the burnt offering as well as twelve rams and twelve year-old male lambs with their grain offering, and there were twelve rams for the sin offering.

88.verse: There were twenty-four bull oxen for the peace offering as well as sixty rams and sixty year-old male lambs. This was the dedication offering after it was anointed.

89.verse: When Moses had gone into the tent of meeting to speak with him, he heard a voice coming from above the mercy seat and between the two cherubim on the Ark of the Covenant speaking to him. So he spoke to him.

1.verse: Chapter 8 -The Lampstand. -The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

2.verse: “Speak to Aaron and say to him, ‘When you set up the lamps, the seven lamps are to shine to the front of the lampstand.’ ”

3.verse: Aaron did this. He set up the lamps so that they faced forward on the lampstand, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.

4.verse: This is how the lampstand was made: it was made from hammered gold from its base to its blossoms. The lampstand was made according to the pattern that the Lord had shown to Moses.

5.verse: Purifying the Levites. -The Lord said to Moses,

6.verse: “Separate the Levites from the other people of Israel and purify them.

7.verse: Do the following to purify them: Sprinkle the water of expiation upon them, and have them shave their entire body and wash their clothes. This will purify them.

8.verse: Let them take a young bull and its cereal offering of fine flour mixed with oil. You shall also take another young bull for a sin offering.

9.verse: You shall present the Levites before the tent of meeting. You shall also gather together the whole assembly of the people of Israel.

10.verse: You shall present the Levites before the Lord, and all the people of Israel will lay their hands upon the Levites.

11.verse: Then Aaron will present the Levites to the Lord as a wave offering of the people of Israel so that they may carry out the work of the Lord.

12.verse: The Levites will lay their hands upon the heads of the young bulls. You will offer one as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering to the Lord to make atonement for the Levites.

13.verse: “You shall have the Levites stand before Aaron and his sons to present them as a wave offering to the Lord.

14.verse: Thus you will separate the Levites from the people of Israel, and the Levites will be mine.

15.verse: After this the Levites can go in and serve the needs of the tent of meeting, when you have purified them and offered them as a wave offering.

16.verse: They are to be wholly dedicated to me from among the people of Israel. I have reserved them for myself as a substitute for all those who open the womb, the firstborn of the people of Israel.

17.verse: All the firstborn of the people of Israel belong to me, both human and animal. I sanctified them to myself on the day that I killed every firstborn in the land of Egypt.

18.verse: But I have taken the Levites as a substitute for all the firstborn of the people of Israel.

19.verse: I have given the Levites as a gift to Aaron and his sons from among the people of Israel, to perform the work of the people of Israel in the tent of meeting and to make atonement for the people of Israel, so that no plague may come upon the people of Israel when the people of Israel approach near the sanctuary.”

20.verse: So Moses and Aaron and all the assembly of the people of Israel did to the Levites what God had commanded Moses concerning the Levites, that is what the people of Israel did to them.

21.verse: The Levites purified themselves and washed their clothes. Aaron presented them as a wave offering to the Lord, and made atonement for them to purify them.

22.verse: Then the Levites went in and performed the work of the tent of meeting under the authority of Aaron and his sons. They did to the Levites the things that the Lord had commanded Moses concerning them.

23.verse: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

24.verse: “The Levites will go in to perform the work of the tent of meeting from the age of twenty-five years old.

25.verse: Then, when they are fifty years old, they will stop performing that service. They will work no more.

26.verse: They may assist their brothers in carrying out the duties of the tent of meeting, but they themselves are not to perform that work. This is how you will establish the responsibilities of the Levites.”

1.verse: Chapter 9 -Observing the Passover. -The Lord spoke to Moses in the Sinai Desert in the first month of the second year after they had come out of the land of Egypt. He said,

2.verse: “Let the people of Israel celebrate the Passover at its appointed time.

3.verse: You will celebrate it at its appointed time, on the fourteenth day of this month, at sunset. You will observe it in accordance with all its statutes; you shall follow all of its ordinances.”

4.verse: So Moses told the people of Israel that they should observe the Passover.

5.verse: They celebrated Passover on the sunset of the fourteenth day of the month in the Sinai Desert. The people of Israel did everything that the Lord had commanded Moses.

6.verse: Now there were some men who had become unclean by touching a dead body, and they could not observe the Passover on that day. They came to Moses and Aaron on that day

7.verse: and they said, “We are unclean because we touched a dead person’s body. Why are we prohibited from presenting an offering to the Lord at its appointed time with the rest of the people of Israel?”

8.verse: Moses said to them, “Stand here, and I will listen to what the Lord commands concerning your situation.”

9.verse: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

10.verse: “Speak to the people of Israel, saying, ‘If any of you or your descendants is unclean because that person comes into contact with a dead body or he is on a journey and is far away, that person shall still observe the Passover of the Lord.

11.verse: You will celebrate it the fourteenth day of the second month, you will eat it with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.

12.verse: You shall not leave any leftovers until the morning, nor shall you break any of its bones. You will observe it according to the ordinances of the Passover of the Lord.

13.verse: “ ‘But if some person is ritually clean and is not off on a journey and that person refuses to observe the Passover, let that person be cut off from among his people. He did not bring his offerings at the appointed time, so he will bear his sin.

14.verse: “ ‘If a foreigner dwelling among you wants to observe the Passover of the Lord, let him do so according to the ordinances of the Passover and according to its ceremonies. There is one set of ordinances for those who are foreigners and for those who were born in the land.’ ”

15.verse: Journeying by the Cloud. -Now on the day that the tabernacle was set up, the cloud covered the tabernacle, the tent of meeting. From evening until morning it appeared in the form of fire.

16.verse: The cloud covered it by day and fire by night.

17.verse: Whenever the cloud was lifted up from the tabernacle, the people of Israel would journey out. The people of Israel would then settle and pitch their tent in the place where the cloud would descend.

18.verse: The people of Israel would journey at the command of the Lord, and they would camp at the command of the Lord. As long as the cloud hovered over the tabernacle, they would stay where they were.

19.verse: Even when the cloud hovered over the tabernacle for several days, the people of Israel would observe the command of the Lord and they would not journey out.

20.verse: At times the cloud would hover over the tabernacle for a few days. They stayed where they were in accordance with the command of the Lord, and they journeyed out in accordance with the command of the Lord.

21.verse: Other times, the cloud would hover from evening until morning, and then the cloud would be lifted up in the morning. They would then journey out. Whether it was by day or by night that the cloud lifted off, it was then that they would journey out.

22.verse: Whether it was two days or a month or a year that the cloud hovered over the tabernacle, the people of Israel would remain where they were. When it was lifted up, then they would journey out.

23.verse: At the command of the Lord, they stayed where they were and at the command of the Lord they journeyed out. They observed the bidding of the Lord, in accordance with the commands of the Lord received through Moses.

1.verse: Chapter 10 -Sounding the Trumpets. -The Lord said to Moses,

2.verse: “Make two trumpets for yourself. Make them from hammered silver. Use them for summoning the assembly and for breaking camp.

3.verse: When they are sounded, the whole assembly will gather before you at the entrance to the tent of meeting.

4.verse: If only one is sounded, the leaders, the heads of the clans of Israel, are to assemble before you.

5.verse: When the advance is sounded, the camps that lie on the east side will set out.

6.verse: With the second blast of the trumpet, the camps that lie to the south side will set out. The trumpet blast will signal their setting out.

7.verse: To gather together the assembly, sound the trumpets but not with the same signal.

8.verse: “The sons of Aaron, the priests, will sound the trumpets. This is to be an everlasting ordinance throughout all your generations.

9.verse: When you go into battle against an enemy who is oppressing you in your own land, sound a blast on the trumpets. Then you will be remembered by the Lord, your God, and you will be saved.

10.verse: Also, at times of rejoicing, your solemn feasts and your new moon celebrations, you are to sound the trumpets over the burnt offerings and the peace offerings. They will be a memorial for you to your God. I am the Lord, your God.”

11.verse: Forty Years in the Wilderness -Departure from Sinai. -On the twentieth day of the second month of the second year, the cloud was lifted up from the tabernacle of the Testimony.

12.verse: The people of Israel set out from the Sinai Desert and traveled until the cloud came to rest in the Desert of Paran.

13.verse: They set out this first time in accord with the command of the Lord received through Moses.

14.verse: The standard of the camp of the tribe of Judah went out first by their companies. Nahshon, the son of Amminadab, was leader of its company.

15.verse: Nethanel, the son of Zuar, was the leader of the company of the tribe of Issachar.

16.verse: Eliab, the son of Helon, was the leader of the company of the tribe of Zebulun.

17.verse: The tabernacle was then taken down, and the Gershonites and the Merarites who carried the tabernacle set out.

18.verse: The standard of the camp of the tribe of Reuben set forth next. Elizur, the son of Shedeur, was the leader of its company.

19.verse: Shelumiel, the son of Zurishaddai, was the leader of the company of the tribe of Simeon.

20.verse: Eliasaph, the son of Reuel, was the leader of the company of the tribe of Gad.

21.verse: Then the Kohathites set forth carrying the sanctuary. The tabernacle was to be set up when they arrived.

22.verse: The standard of the camp of the tribe of Ephraim came next. Elishama, the son of Ammihud, was the leader of its company.

23.verse: Gamaliel, the son of Pedahzur, was the leader of the company of the tribe of Manasseh.

24.verse: Abidan, the son of Gideoni, was the leader of the company of the tribe of Benjamin.

25.verse: Finally, behind all of the other camps, the standard of the camp of the tribe of Dan set out. Ahiezer, the son of Ammishaddai, was the leader of its company.

26.verse: Pagiel, the son of Ochran, was the leader of the company of the tribe of Asher.

27.verse: Ahira, the son of Enan, was the leader of the company of the tribe of Naphtali.

28.verse: This was the order of the companies of the people of Israel as they set out.

29.verse: Plea to Hobab. -Moses said to Hobab, the son of Reuel the Midianite, Moses’ father-in-law, “We are setting out for the place that the Lord said, ‘I will give it to you.’ Come with us and we will treat you well, for the Lord has promised good things to Israel.”

30.verse: But he said to him, “I will not go, rather I will leave for my own land and my own people.”

31.verse: But he said, “Please do not leave us. You know where we should camp in the desert, and you could look out for us.

32.verse: If you come with us, then whatever good things the Lord bestows upon us, we will share them with you.”

33.verse: Into the Wilderness. -They traveled a three days’ journey from the mountain of the Lord, and the Ark of the Covenant went before them throughout the three days’ journey, searching out a resting place for them.

34.verse: The cloud of the Lord was over them by day when they set out from the camp.

35.verse: Whenever the Ark set forth, Moses would say,“Rise up, O Lord, let your enemies be scattered.Let those who hate you flee before you.”

36.verse: Whenever it rested he said,“Return, O Lord, to the thousands upon thousands of Israel.”

1.verse: Chapter 11 -The People of Israel Complain. -The people complained about their hardships and the Lord heard and his anger flared up. Then the fire of the Lord burned up the outskirts of the camp.

2.verse: The people cried out to Moses, and Moses prayed to the Lord, and the fire was quenched.

3.verse: He named that place Taberah, for the fire of the Lord had burned in their midst.

4.verse: Now the rabble among them fell victim to their desires again, and the people of Israel said, “Who will give us meat to eat?

5.verse: We remember the fish we ate freely in Egypt, along with the cucumbers, the melons, the leeks, the onions, and the garlic.

6.verse: But now our strength is fading away, all we ever see is this manna.”

7.verse: Manna had the shape of coriander seed and it looked like resin.

8.verse: The people would go around gathering it, and then they would grind it in a mill or beat it in a mortar. They cooked it in a pot or made it into cakes. It tasted something like fresh olive oil.

9.verse: The manna would come down when the dew settled upon the camp at night.

10.verse: Moses heard the people weeping, each family at the entrance to their tent. The Lord became exceedingly angry, and Moses was greatly displeased.

11.verse: Moses said to the Lord, “Why are you torturing your servant? Have I not found favor in your sight, that you would burden me with this whole people?

12.verse: Did I conceive this entire people? Did I give birth to them that you should say to me, ‘Carry them in your arms like a nurse carries a small child to the land that I have promised to their ancestors?’

13.verse: Where can I get enough meat to give to all this people, for they cry to me saying, ‘Give us meat to eat!’

14.verse: I cannot carry this entire people by myself; they are too burdensome for me.

15.verse: If this is the way that you are going to treat me, and if I have found favor in your sight, then please put me to death right now so I do not have to keep looking upon my misery.”

16.verse: But the Lord said to Moses, “Bring me seventy men from among the elders of Israel whom you know to be elders and leaders of the people. Bring them to the tent of meeting, and have them stand there with yourself.

17.verse: I will come down and speak to you there. I will take some of the Spirit that is upon you and put it upon them. They will carry the burden of the people with you, so that you do not have to carry it alone.

18.verse: Say to the people, ‘Consecrate yourselves, for tomorrow you will eat meat. You cried out in the hearing of the Lord, saying, “Who will give us meat to eat? We were better off when we were in Egypt.” Now the Lord will give you meat, and you will eat it.

19.verse: You will not eat it for just one day, nor for two days, nor for five days, nor for ten days, nor for twenty days.

20.verse: You will eat it for a whole month, until your faces overflow with it, and you become sick of it, for you have despised the Lord who is among you and whom you have confronted crying out, “Why did we come out of Egypt?” ’ ”

21.verse: But Moses said, “I am standing among six hundred thousand people on foot, and you have said, ‘I will give them meat to eat for an entire month?’

22.verse: Shall the flocks and herds be slaughtered to satisfy their desires? Will all of the fish of the sea be gathered together to fill them?”

23.verse: The Lord answered Moses, “Is the Lord’s power limited? Now you will see whether my word will be fulfilled or not.”

24.verse: Seventy Elders. -So Moses went out and proclaimed the words of the Lord to the people. He brought seventy of the elders of the people and placed them around the tabernacle.

25.verse: Then the Lord came down in a cloud and spoke to him. He took some of the Spirit that was upon him and placed it upon the seventy elders. When the Spirit descended upon them, they began to prophesy, although they did not do so again.

26.verse: But two men had remained in the camp. One was named Eldad, and the other was named Medad. The Spirit descended upon them. They had been on the list, but they had not gone out to the tabernacle. They began to prophesy in the camp.

27.verse: A young man ran and informed Moses, saying, “Eldad and Medad are prophesying in the camp.”

28.verse: Joshua, the son of Nun, who had been an aide to Moses since he was young, said, “My lord Moses, stop them.”

29.verse: But Moses said to him, “Are you jealous for me? Would that all of the Lord’s people were prophets, that the Lord would put his Spirit upon them!”

30.verse: Moses then returned to the camp, he and the elders of Israel.

31.verse: Now a wind came forth from the Lord, and it brought quail from the sea, making them fall near the camp. They were all around the camp, a day’s journey on one side and a day’s journey on the other side. They were piled up on the surface of the land two cubits high.

32.verse: The people stayed up all day, and all night, and all the next day gathering the quail. The least that any of them gathered was ten homers. They spread them out for themselves all around the camp.

33.verse: But while the meat was still between their teeth and they were still chewing on it, the anger of the Lord arose against the people and the Lord struck the people with a horrible plague.

34.verse: This is why that place was called Kibroth-hattaavah, because they buried the people who had fallen victim to their desires there.

35.verse: From Kibroth-hattaavah the people traveled to Hazeroth and they camped there.

1.verse: Chapter 12 -Miriam and Aaron Oppose Moses. -Miriam and Aaron criticized Moses because of the Ethiopian woman whom he had married, for he had married an Ethiopian woman.

2.verse: They said, “Has the Lord only spoken through Moses? Has he not also spoken through us?” And the Lord heard this.

3.verse: Now Moses was very humble, more so than anyone else upon the face of the earth.

4.verse: Suddenly the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron and Miriam, saying, “Come out, you three, from the tent of meeting.” And the three of them came out.

5.verse: The Lord came down in a pillar of cloud and stood at the entrance to the tabernacle and summoned Aaron and Miriam, and they both came forward.

6.verse: He said, “Hear now my words:“If anyone among you is a prophet,I, the Lord, make myself known to him in a vision,I speak to him in a dream.

7.verse: It is not that way with Moses,who is entrusted with all my household.

8.verse: I speak to him face to face,clearly, and not in riddles.He beholds the very form of the Lord.Why then were you not afraid to criticize my servant Moses?”

9.verse: Then the anger of the Lord blazed against them, and he departed.

10.verse: Miriam’s Punishment. -When the cloud lifted up off of the tabernacle, there stood Miriam, leprous, white as snow. Aaron turned toward Miriam and saw that she was a leper.

11.verse: Aaron said to Moses, “Please, my lord, do not hold the sin against us that we have so foolishly committed!

12.verse: Let her not be like a stillborn child who comes forth from its mother’s womb with its flesh half eaten away.”

13.verse: Moses cried out to the Lord, “O God, I beseech you, heal her!”

14.verse: The Lord replied to Moses, “If her father had only spit in her face, would she not have been shamed for seven days? Confine her outside of the camp for seven days. After that, let her be received back in.”

15.verse: So Miriam was confined outside of the camp for seven days. The people did not move on until Miriam was brought back in.

16.verse: After this, the people left Hazeroth and they camped in the Desert of Paran.

1.verse: Chapter 13 -Twelve Scouts. -The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

2.verse: “Send some men out to explore the land of Canaan that I am giving to the people of Israel. Send one of the leaders from each of the ancestral tribes.”

3.verse: So Moses sent them out from the Desert of Paran by command of the Lord, each of them being one of the heads of the people of Israel.

4.verse: These are their names:from the tribe of Reuben there was Shammua, the son of Zaccur;

5.verse: from the tribe of Simeon there was Shaphat, the son of Hori;

6.verse: from the tribe of Judah there was Caleb, the son of Jephunneh;

7.verse: from the tribe of Issachar there was Igal, the son of Joseph;

8.verse: from the tribe of Ephraim there was Hoshea, the son of Nun;

9.verse: from the tribe of Benjamin there was Palti, the son of Raphu;

10.verse: from the tribe of Zebulun there was Gaddiel, the son of Sodi;

11.verse: from the tribe of Joseph, that is, from the tribe of Manasseh, there was Gaddi, the son of Susi;

12.verse: from the tribe of Dan there was Ammiel, the son of Gemalli;

13.verse: from the tribe of Asher there was Sethur, the son of Michael;

14.verse: from the tribe of Naphtali there was Nahbi, the son of Vophsi;

15.verse: and from the tribe of Gad there was Geuel, the son of Machi.

16.verse: These are the names of those whom Moses sent to explore the land. Moses gave Hoshea, the son of Nun, the name Joshua.

17.verse: Moses sent them to explore the land of Canaan. He said to them, “Go up into the Negeb, then go up into the hill country.

18.verse: See what the land is like. Discover whether the people who live there are strong or weak, few or many.

19.verse: How is the land upon which they are living, is it good or bad? How are the cities in which they dwell, are they open camps or fortified?

20.verse: How is the land, is it fertile or poor? Are there trees or not? Try to bring back some of the fruit of the land” (for it was the season of the first ripe grapes).

21.verse: So they went up and explored the land, from the Desert of Zin up to Rehob, near the entrance to Lebo-hamath.

22.verse: They went up into the Negeb and came to Hebron where Ahiman, Sheshai, and Talmai, descendants of Anak dwelt. (Now Hebron was built seven years before Zoan in Egypt.)

23.verse: Then they came to the Valley of Eshcol. There they cut down a branch with a single cluster of grapes. Two men carried it on a pole. They also brought along some pomegranates and figs.

24.verse: That place was called the Valley of Eschol because of the cluster of grapes that the people of Israel cut there.

25.verse: The Scouts’ Report. -They returned from exploring the land at the end of forty days.

26.verse: They left and went back to Moses and Aaron and the whole assembly of the people of Israel that was camped in Kadesh in the Desert of Paran. They brought back a report to them and showed the whole assembly the fruit of the land.

27.verse: Then they told Moses, “We went into the land into which you sent us, and it truly flows with milk and honey. This is its fruit.

28.verse: However, a powerful people dwells in that land, and the cities are highly fortified. Furthermore, we even saw the descendants of Anak there.

29.verse: The Amalekites live in the land of the Negeb, and the Hittites, the Jebusites, and the Amorites live in the hill country. The Canaanites live by the sea and along the banks of the Jordan.”

30.verse: Then Caleb quieted the people who were standing before Moses and he said, “Let us go at once to take possession of it, for we shall surely conquer it.”

31.verse: But the men who had gone up with him said, “We will not be able to go up against the people for they are surely stronger than we are.”

32.verse: Thus, they brought a negative report of the land which they had explored for the people of Israel saying, “The land which we went through to explore is a land that devours its inhabitants. All the people we saw in it were immense.

33.verse: We saw giants there, the descendants of Anak (the Anak come from the Nephilim). We felt as if we were only grasshoppers, and we seemed like that to them.”

1.verse: Chapter 14 -The People Rebel. -The whole assembly cried out and wept loudly that night.

2.verse: All the people of Israel grumbled against Moses and Aaron. The whole assembly said to them, “Would that we would have died in Egypt, or we had died in this desert!

3.verse: Why did the Lord bring us into this land so that we fall by the sword? Our wives and our children will be taken as plunder! Would it not be better for us to return to Egypt?”

4.verse: They said to one another, “Let us choose a leader who will take us back to Egypt.”

5.verse: Moses and Aaron fell on their faces before the whole assembly of the people of Israel gathered there.

6.verse: Joshua, the son of Nun, and Caleb, the son of Jephunneh, who had spied out the land, tore their clothes.

7.verse: They spoke to the entire assembly of the people of Israel saying, “The land we passed through and explored is a tremendously good land.

8.verse: If the Lord is pleased with us, he will lead us into that land and give it to us, a land flowing with milk and honey.

9.verse: Only do not rebel against the Lord, nor be afraid of the people of the land, for we will devour them. Their protection is gone, and the Lord is with us. Do not fear them!”The Lord’s Response. -

10.verse: But the whole assembly decided to stone them. Then the glory of the Lord appeared in the tent of meeting in front of all of the people of Israel.

11.verse: The Lord said to Moses, “How long will this people despise me? How long before they trust me, in spite of all the signs that I have performed in their midst?

12.verse: I will strike them down with a plague and I will destroy them. Then I will make a nation arise from you that is greater and mightier than they are.”

13.verse: But Moses said to the Lord, “The Egyptians will hear about it, for by your power you brought this people out from their midst.

14.verse: They will report it to the people of this land. They have heard that you, O Lord, are in the midst of this people, for you, O Lord, are seen face to face. Your cloud stands over them, and you go before them as a cloud by day and as a pillar of fire by night.

15.verse: Now if you kill this people as if it were a single man, then the nations that have heard of your fame will say,

16.verse: ‘The Lord was not able to bring this people into the land that he promised them, so he killed them in the wilderness.’

17.verse: Therefore, my Lord, show your great power, for as you have declared,

18.verse: ‘The Lord is slow to anger and abounding in mercy, forgiving sin and rebellion. Yet he does not leave the guilty unpunished, visiting the iniquity of the father upon the sons to the third and fourth generation.’

19.verse: By your great mercy, I beseech you, forgive this people, just as you have forgiven this people ever since they left Egypt until now.”

20.verse: The Lord answered, “I have forgiven them, just as you have asked.

21.verse: But assuredly, just as I live and the glory of the Lord fills the whole earth,

22.verse: because this entire people has witnessed my glory and the miracles that I performed in Egypt and in the wilderness, and yet they have put me to the test these ten times and have not heeded my voice,

23.verse: none of them will see the land that I promised to their fathers. None of those who despised me will see it.

24.verse: But I will bring my servant Caleb into the land that he entered because he has a different spirit and wholeheartedly follows me. His descendants will inherit it.

25.verse: Turn back tomorrow and set out for the wilderness along the route to the Red Sea for the Amalekites and the Canaanites are living in the valley.”

26.verse: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,

27.verse: “How long will this wicked assembly grumble against me? I have heard the complaints of the people of Israel that they grumble against me.

28.verse: So I declare to them: As I live, says the Lord, I will make the things you have said in my hearing happen:

29.verse: your dead bodies will fall to the ground in this wilderness. None of you who are twenty years or older and who have complained about me

30.verse: will enter the land in which I swore I would make you dwell except for Caleb, the son of Jephunneh, and Joshua, the son of Nun.

31.verse: However, as for your little ones whom you said would become plunder, I will bring them in and they will come to know the land that you have despised.

32.verse: But your dead bodies will fall to the ground in this wilderness.

33.verse: Your children will wander in this wilderness for forty years, and they will bear the burden of your unfaithfulness, until your dead bodies lie in the wilderness.

34.verse: The number of days that you explored the land was forty, and there will be one year for each day. You will bear the burden of your sins for forty years and you will come to know my rejection.

35.verse: I, the Lord, have proclaimed this. I will surely do this to this evil assembly that has gathered together against me. In this wilderness they will come to an end, there they will die.”

36.verse: The men whom Moses sent to explore the land, and who, when they returned, incited the assembly to complain against him by giving an evil report concerning the land,

37.verse: those men who brought the evil report concerning the land were struck down by a plague before the Lord.

38.verse: Of the men who went to explore the land, Joshua, the son of Nun, and Caleb, the son of Jephunneh, survived.

39.verse: Doomed Invasion. -When Moses reported these sayings to all the people of Israel, the people mourned bitterly.

40.verse: They rose up early the next morning and went to the top of the mountain and said, “Here we are! We have sinned, but we are ready to go up to the place that the Lord has promised.”

41.verse: But Moses said, “Why are you now disobeying the command of the Lord? This will not succeed.

42.verse: Do not go up, for the Lord is not with you. You will be defeated by your enemies.

43.verse: The Amalekites and the Canaanites are there in front of you. You will fall by the sword, because you turned away from the Lord. The Lord will not be with you.”

44.verse: In their presumption, they went up into the high hill country, but the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord and Moses did not go out from the camp.

45.verse: The Amalekites and the Canaanites who lived in the hill country came down and attacked them and drove them back to Hormah.

1.verse: Chapter 15 -Additional Offerings. -The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

2.verse: “Speak to the people of Israel and say to them: ‘When you come into the land of your dwelling that I will give you

3.verse: and you make an offering by fire to the Lord, either a burnt offering or a sacrifice, whether to fulfill a vow or as a freewill offering or on your appointed feast days, whether it be from the herd or the flock, in order to make a pleasing fragrance to the Lord,

4.verse: then the person bringing his offering to the Lord should bring a cereal offering of a tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with a fourth of a hin of oil.

5.verse: With each burnt offering or sacrifice of a lamb you are to make a drink offering of a quarter of a hin of wine.

6.verse: For a ram, you are to make a cereal offering of two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with a third of a hin of oil,

7.verse: and for a drink offering you are to offer a third of a hin of wine, a pleasing fragrance to the Lord.

8.verse: “ ‘When you prepare a young bull as a burnt offering or a sacrifice, whether to fulfill a vow or to make a peace offering to the Lord,

9.verse: you will offer a cereal offering of three-tenths of an ephah of fine flour, mixed with half a hin of oil along with the young bull,

10.verse: and you will bring a drink offering of half a hin of wine. It will be an offering made by fire, a pleasing fragrance to the Lord.

11.verse: Each young bull or each ram, each lamb or each kid goat is to be prepared in this way.

12.verse: Whatever number you prepare, you shall do this with each one.

13.verse: “ ‘All who were born in the land will do things this way when they present an offering by fire, a pleasing fragrance to the Lord.

14.verse: If there is a foreigner living among you or a person living among you for generations, and he wishes to make an offering by fire, a pleasing fragrance to the Lord, let him do it as you have done it.

15.verse: For the community, there is one ordinance for you and for the foreigner living in your midst, it is a perpetual ordinance for all your generations. Thus, you and the foreigner are the same before the Lord.

16.verse: The same laws and statutes apply to you and the foreigner who is living in your midst.’ ”

17.verse: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

18.verse: “Speak to the people of Israel and tell them, ‘When you enter into the land to which I am bringing you,

19.verse: then when you eat the food of the land, you shall lift up an offering to the Lord.

20.verse: You shall lift up a cake from the first of your dough as an offering just as you present an offering from your threshing floor.

21.verse: You shall give an offering to the Lord from the first of your dough for all your generations.

22.verse: Atonement Offerings. -“ ‘If by mistake you have not observed all the commandments that the Lord proclaimed through Moses,

23.verse: all that the Lord commanded through Moses, from the day that the Lord gave the commandments and onward through all your generations,

24.verse: this is what will be done: if the action was committed unintentionally and without the knowledge of the assembly, then the whole assembly is to offer up one young bull as a burnt offering, a pleasing fragrance to the Lord, along with its cereal and drink offerings, according to custom, as well as one kid goat as a sin offering.

25.verse: The priest shall make atonement for the whole assembly of the people of Israel, and it will be forgiven them, for it was unintentional. They will have brought a sacrifice by fire to the Lord, a sin offering to the Lord for their mistake.

26.verse: All of the assembly of the people of Israel and even the foreigner living among them shall be forgiven, for all the people participated in the mistake.

27.verse: “ ‘If a person sins unintentionally, then he is to offer up a year-old she-goat as a sin offering.

28.verse: The priest is to make atonement before the Lord for the one who has sinned unintentionally. When atonement has been made for him, he will be forgiven.

29.verse: You shall have one law for those who sin unintentionally, whether they were born among the people of Israel or they are foreigners living in your midst.

30.verse: “ ‘But if someone does anything defiantly, whether he be native born or a foreigner, then that person blasphemes the Lord and is to be cut off from among his people.

31.verse: Because he has despised the word of the Lord and has broken his commandment, let that person be completely cut off, and let his guilt remain upon him.’ ”

32.verse: Sabbath-breaker Punished. -Now, while the people of Israel were in the desert, they came upon a man gathering wood on the Sabbath.

33.verse: Those who found him gathering wood brought him to Moses and Aaron and to the whole assembly

34.verse: and they put him under guard, for it had not yet been established what was to be done to him.

35.verse: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Surely the man is to be put to death! Let the whole assembly stone him outside of the camp!”

36.verse: So the whole assembly took him outside of the camp, and they stoned him to death, as the Lord had commanded Moses.

37.verse: Tassels on Garments. -The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

38.verse: “Speak to the people of Israel and tell them to have tassels on the corners of their garments throughout all their generations. Let them put a blue cord on the tassels of each corner.

39.verse: When you look at the tassels, you will remember the commandments of the Lord and keep them. Thus you will not prostitute yourselves by following after the lusts in your own heart or your own eyes.

40.verse: Then you will remember to obey all the commandments and you will be holy to your God.

41.verse: I am the Lord, your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt to be your God. I am the Lord, your God.”

1.verse: Chapter 16 -Korah’s Rebellion. -Korah, the son of Izhar, the son of Kohath, the son of Levi, and some Reubenites, Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, and On, the son of Peleth took action

2.verse: and rose up against Moses. With them were some of the people of Israel, two hundred fifty leaders of the assembly, well known in the assembly and men of renown.

3.verse: They gathered together against Moses and Aaron and said to them, “You have gone too far! The whole assembly is holy, every one of them, and the Lord is in their midst. Why, then, do you exalt yourselves above the assembly of the Lord?”

4.verse: When Moses heard this he fell on his face

5.verse: and he spoke to Korah and his company, saying, “Tomorrow the Lord will reveal who belongs to him and who is holy when he allows him to approach him. He will allow the one whom he has chosen to approach him.

6.verse: Do this: you and Korah and all his followers are to take censers

7.verse: before the Lord tomorrow and put fire and incense in them. The man whom the Lord chooses shall be the holy one. You have gone too far, you Levites!”

8.verse: Then Moses said to Korah, “Hear now, you Levites,

9.verse: is it not enough that the God of Israel has set you apart from the assembly of Israel to bring you onto himself, to minister in the tabernacle of the Lord, and to stand before the assembly serving them?

10.verse: He has brought you and all your brethren, the Levites, onto himself, and still you seek the priesthood too?

11.verse: For this you and all your company have gathered together against the Lord. Who is Aaron that you should complain about him?”

12.verse: Rebellion of Dathan and Abiram. -Then Moses summoned Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab. They responded, “We will not come up!

13.verse: Is it not enough that you brought us out of a land flowing with milk and honey to kill us in the desert? Now you are going to make yourself a prince over us?
